choices.text: Cerebral vein thrombosis
Meningitis
Subarachnoid hemorrhage
Cavernous sinus thrombosis

questions.text: A 30 year old P2L2 presents 5 days after a normal delivery with complaints of headache and vomiting. On fundus examination, papilledema is seen with no other focal signs. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cerebral vein thrombosis

  • The clinical features given in the question are suggestive of raised ICP, commonly seen in Cerebral vein thrombosis.
  • It is one of the common neurological complications seen in puerperium.
  • Absence of focal deficits further points towards this diagnosis.
  • Meningitis, SAH and cavernous sinus mostly have a different presentation and are not so common after pregnancy.

Cerebral venous thrombosis

  • Thrombosis of the lateral or superior sagittal venous sinus usually occurs in the puerperium and often in association with preeclampsia, sepsis, or thrombophilia.
  • It is more common in patients with inherited thrombophilia, lupus anticoagulant, or antiphospholipid antibodies.
  • Headache is the most common presenting symptom, neurological deficits are common, and up to a third of patients have convulsions.
  • Diagnosis is with MR venography.
  • Management includes anticonvulsants for seizures.
  • Antimicrobials are given if there is septic thrombophlebitis, and fibrinolytic therapy is reserved for those women failing systemic anticoagulation.
  • The prognosis for venous thrombosis in pregnancy is better than in nonpregnant subjects.

 

Ref: Page no 1132, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

choices.text: Amniotic fluid embolism
Fat embolism
DIC
Pulmonary embolism

questions.text: A patient who delivered a few hours back collapses and dies. During autopsy, alveolar fluid analysis shows presence of hair and squamous epithelial cells. Most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amniotic fluid embolism

Amniotic Fluid Embolism

Complex condition characterized by abrupt onset of pulmonary embolism, shock and DIC which is due to entering of amniotic fluid into the maternal circulation.

Incidence - 1 in 8,000 to 1 in 80,000 pregnancies.

Time of event

  • During labor (history may be occurring after artificial rupture of membranes)
  • During C/S
  • After normal vaginal delivery

Pathophysiology:

Criteria For Diagnosis (Williams 26th edition)

  • Sudden onset of cardiopulmonary arrest or both Hypotension and Respiratory compromise
  • DIC following initial symptoms
  • Onset during labor or within 30 minutes of delivery
  • No fever (>38.0°C) during labor

Other important Points

  • More than 50% of patients die within the first hour.
  • 50% of the survivors will develop DIC which may manifest as persistent bleeding from incision or venipuncture sites.
  • 10-15% of patients will develop grand mal seizures.
  • CXR may be normal or show effusions, enlarged heart or pulmonary edema.
  • ECG may show a right strain pattern with ST-T changes and tachycardia.
  • The presence of squamous cells in the pulmonary vasculature once considered pathognomonic for AFE is neither sensitive nor specific (only 73% of patients dying from AFE had this finding).
  • The monoclonal antibody TKAH-2 may eventually prove more useful in the rapid diagnosis of AFE. Investigations: CBC, ABG, PT, aPTT, fibrinogen, FDP.

Remember:

In AFE: 1st collapse, then bleeding (due to DIC)

In PPH: 1st bleeding then collapse

Goals of Management

  • Restoration of cardiovascular and pulmonary equilibrium 
    • Maintain systolic blood pressure >90 mm Hg.
    • Urine output> 25 mI/hr.
    • Arterial pO2> 60 mm Hg.
  • Re-establishing uterine tone.
  • Correct coagulation abnormalities.
  • As intubation and CPR may be required, it is necessary to have easy access to the patient, experienced help, and a resuscitation tray with intubation equipment, DC shock and emergency medications.

Ref: Page no 743-745, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

choices.text: In non-lactating mothers, ovulation may occur as early as 42 days
Colostrum has low proteins, high carbohydrates and high fat content as compared to breast milk.
Involution of the uterus is delayed if the woman delivers a still-born baby
Beta-hCG can be detected upto 3 weeks in the maternal serum after delivery

questions.text: Which one of the following statements relating to puerperium is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Colostrum has low proteins, high carbohydrates and high fat content as compared to breast milk.

Advantages of colostrum:

      • Antibodies (IgA, IgG, IgM) and humoral factors (lactoferrin) provide immunological defense to the newborn.
      • It has laxative action on the baby because of large fat globules
      • IT has more protein but less carbohydrate and less fat than breast milk

Other Options

  • In women who are not breastfeeding, ovulation occurs as early as 6 weeks post delivery
  • Causes of subinvolution are.
    • Retained placenta
    • Overdistended uterus in the antepartum period (macrosomia, multiple pregnancy, polyhydramnios)
    • Fibroid uterus
    • Endometritis
    • No lactation (As in a still-born baby) as oxytocin is not secreted
    • Anemia
    • Primipara
  • Serum bhCG can persist uptil 3 weeks following delivery (average 14 days; range 8-24 days) 

Educational Objective

Ref: Williams 26th edition page no 637

choices.text: Dilatation and Evacuation
IV antibiotics
Reassurance
Ultrasound pelvis

questions.text: You are called to the postnatal ward to see a patient who has delivered a 3.4kg boy 1 day earlier by a vaginal delivery. She was a known case of gestational diabetes mellitus. She is anxious as she is having mild bleeding. On examination she is afebrile. PR is 80/ min. BP is 110/70 mmHg. On abdominal exam, the uterus is just below the umbilicus and on local examination, the episiotomy appears healthy and the pad is stained with blood. There is no foul smell. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Reassurance

 

  • This patient is in the puerperal period who is complaining of bloody discharge with no other significant abnormal signs. On examination, her vitals are normal, suggesting that the bleeding is not excessive

  • The uterus is also as would be expected for the 1st postnatal day and there are no signs of infection

  • The patient needs to be counseled that this is lochia rubra and will be there for a few days followed by blood mixed discharge and then whitish discharge (lochia rubra f/b lochia serosa f/b lochia alba)

  • Slight amount of bloody discharge called lochia is normal for the first 15 days after delivery and does not require any treatment, so we will reassure the patient and do nothing.

  • Mild leukocytosis with predominant granulocytes is a normal finding in the puerperal period .

  • Leucocytes can rise to as high as 25000 during puerperium probably as a response to the stress of labor

  • Since lochia has no foul smell it means no infection and so no need for culture or antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Dilatation and Curettage: This is not done. A dilatation and evacuation with very gentle curettage is done when there is retained placenta. This will usually present as puerperal fever or secondary PPH

 

Option B: IV antibiotics: Also not recommeded in this case as there are no signs of puerperal fever/ infection. 

 

Option D: Ultrasound: This is indicated if there is suspicion of retained placental bits which is not seen here

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The normal discharge following delivery is called Lochia

 

Lochia is of 3 types

 

  1. Lochia Rubra: lasts for 5-7 days, red in color

  2. Lochia serosa: lasts for 7-10 days, pinkish-yellow

  3. Lochia alba: lasts for 10-25 days, white in color

 

Ref: Page: 636-637 Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Rubra, serosa, alba
Serosa, rubra, alba
Alba, serosa, rubra
Alba, mucosa, serosa

questions.text: Is Lochia in correct order during puerperium?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rubra, serosa, alba

LOCHIA:

  • It is the vaginal discharge for the first few weeks during puerperium.
  • The discharge originates from the uterine body, cervix and vagina
  • It has got a peculiar offensive fishy smell.
  • Its reaction is alkaline tending to become acidic towards the end.
  • Depending upon the variation of the color of the discharge, it is named as:
    • Lochia rubra (red) 1-4 days.
    • Lochia serosa (5-9 days) — the color is yellowish or pink or pale brownish.
    • Lochia alba — (pale white) — 10-15 days.

Composition:

  1. Lochia rubra consists of blood, shreds of fetal membranes and decidua, vernix caseosa, lanugo and meconium.
  2. Lochia serosa consists of less RBC but more leukocytes, wound exudate, mucus from the cervix and microorganisms (anaerobic streptococci and staphylococci).
  3. Lochia alba contains plenty of decidual cells, leukocytes, mucus, cholesterol crystals, fatty and granular epithelial cells and microorganisms.

 

Ref: Page 636, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Puerperal blues
Puerperal depression
Puerperal insomnia
Puerperal anxiety

questions.text: A 28 yr woman is on her 3rd postnatal day. A psychiatric consultation is sought in view of occasional crying episodes, fatigue and lack of sleep. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Puerperal blues

 

Ref: Page 645, Williams 26th Edition

choices.text: Within 10 mins of placental delivery
Within 24 h of delivery
Within 48h of delivery
Within the 1st month of delivery

questions.text: A 23 year old woman has just delivered her 2nd baby. She asks the resident for a contraceptive method. The resident suggests an intrauterine copper containing device. How soon after delivery can this be inserted?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Within 10 mins of placental delivery.

  • The IUD can be inserted as early as within 10 minutes of expulsion of the placenta. This is called postplacental insertion.
  • Timing of Intrauterine device insertion
    • Post Placental (Within 10 minutes of placental delivery)
    • Intra cesarean (At the time of cesarean after delivery of the placenta)
    • Within the 1st 48 h (Early postpartum)
    • At 6 weeks of delivery (Late postpartum)
    • Interval (Any time; preferably post menstrual and reasonably certain patient is not pregnant)
    • Post abortal.

 

Ref:https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/family-planing/guidelines/IUCD_Reference_Manual_for_MOs_and_Nursing_Personne_-Final-Sept_2013.pdf

choices.text: The 1st 4 weeks following delivery
The 1st 6 weeks following delivery
The 1st 12 weeks following delivery
The 1st 24 weeks following delivery

questions.text: The 4th trimester of pregnancy refers to?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. The 1st 12 weeks following delivery

  • The 4th trimester of pregnancy is an important new concept
  • The ACOG says the 4th trimester of pregnancy is the 3 months following delivery
  • This includes physical, social and psychological well being of the mother during the 3 months after delivery
  • An initial visit at 3 weeks is now recommended following delivery
  • And a final summary visit at 12 weeks

 

 

Ref: Page no 634, 26th edition Williams Obstetrics

choices.text: Inj Cefazolin at the time of skin incision
Inj Co-Amoxiclav at the time of skin incision
Inj Cefazolin at the time of spinal anesthesia
Inj Co-Amoxiclav at the time of spinal anesthesia

questions.text: A 34 yr woman is undergoing an elective cesarean for breech presentation. You are the resident in charge of her case. What is the antibiotic you will recommend and when should it be given?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Inj Cefazolin at the time of skin incision

Peri – Operative Prophylaxis guidelines for delivery

  • For cesarean section and operative vaginal delivery, the following help reduce the incidence of pelvic and wound infection
    • Peri operative antibiotics (1st gen Cephalosporin at the time of skin incision)
    • Skin preparation (Chlorhexidine-alcohol)
  • Perioperative antibiotics may also reduce the pelvic infection rates following operative vaginal delivery
  • Insufficient evidence to recommend routine perioperative antibiotics following routine delivery OR Episiotomy OR manual removal of placenta

 

REF: Page no 652, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

choices.text: Institute Sitz bath several times a day.
Scrub wounds twice daily with povidone-iodine
Broad spectrum antibiotics to be given intravenously.
Debride wound followed by immediate wound closure.

questions.text: A 24 yr P1L1 who had a vaginal delivery 10 days earlier presents with gaping at the episiotomy site associated with a foul smell. Which is incorrect regarding management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Debride wound followed by immediate wound closure.

Preoperative Protocol for Early Repair of Episiotomy Dehiscence

  • Open wound, remove sutures, begin IV antimicrobials.
  • Initiate wound care.
    • Institute sitz bath several times a day.
    • Provide adequate analgesia/ anesthesia
    • Scrub wound twice daily with a povidone-iodine solution
    • Debride necrotic tissue.
  • Close wound when afebrile and pink, health granulation tissue present
  • Provide enemas to 3rd and 4th degree repair
  • Institute post operative stool softeners; normal diet nothing per vagina or rectum

 

Ref: Page no 658, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Normal postpartum period; reassurance
Puerperal sepsis; broad-spectrum antibiotics
Postpartum hemorrhage; uterine massage
Preeclampsia; antihypertensive medication

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman delivered her first child two days ago. She now presents with low-grade fever, uterine tenderness, and foul-smelling vaginal discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the recommended treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Puerperal sepsis; broad-spectrum antibiotics

 

Explanation: The clinical presentation of low-grade fever, uterine tenderness, and foul-smelling discharge is suggestive of puerperal sepsis, which is an infection of the reproductive tract. Treatment involves broad-spectrum antibiotics.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A: Normal puerperium is not associated with foul smelling discharge and fever or uterine tenderness, the normal puerperal vaginal discharge is referred to as lochia.
  • Option C: Post partum hemorrhage presents as heavy vaginal bleeding
  • Option D: Pre-eclampsia and PPH do not cause foul smelling discharge or fever

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Puerperal fever is defined as fever > 100.4°F OR > 38°C on more than 2 occasions after 24h of delivery
  • Puerperal sepsis is defined as an infection of the genital tract occurring at any time between the onset of rupture of membranes or labor and the 42nd day post-partum with
  • Puerperal fever
  • Abnormal vaginal discharge
  • Foul smelling vaginal discharge
  • Uterine sub-involution

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition pg 667

choices.text: Combined oral contraceptives
Withdrawal method
Progestin-only contraceptives
Barrier methods

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, P2L2, gave birth to a healthy baby girl. She is breastfeeding and is concerned about her postpartum contraception options. What is the most suitable method for postpartum contraception during lactation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Progestin-only contraceptives

 

Explanation:

 

  • During lactation, progestin-only contraceptives are generally the most suitable method as they do not interfere with breastfeeding and have a lower risk of side effects compared to combined oral contraceptives.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option. A. Combined oral contraceptives: Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) contain both estrogen and progestin. These are not typically recommended for breastfeeding women, especially in the immediate postpartum period, because estrogen can reduce milk supply. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends avoiding these during the first six months postpartum for women who are breast feeding
  • Option B. Withdrawal method: is a natural method wit very high failure rate and hence not preferred
  • Option D. Barrier methods: Barrier methods include condoms, diaphragms, and cervical caps. These do not interfere with breastfeeding. However, they are generally less effective at preventing pregnancy than hormonal methods or IUDs

 

Thus, while breastfeeding, progestin-only contraceptives are considered the most appropriate option due to their minimal impact on milk production and safety for the infant

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contraceptives in breast feeding women

 

  • Prefer Progesterone containing contraceptives as they do not interfere with lactation and do not increase the risk of thrombo-embolism
  • Intra-uterine devices can also be used. These are to be inserted either within 48h of birth or after 6 weeks of delivery

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition pg 177

choices.text: Blood pressure monitoring
Pelvic examination
Pap smear
Contraceptive counseling

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, P1L1, is attending her postpartum visit. She gave birth vaginally four weeks ago. Her vital signs are stable, and she has no complaints. What is the most important component of the postpartum visit for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Contraceptive counseling

 

Explanation:

 

  • Contraceptive counseling is a crucial component of the postpartum visit, ensuring that the patient is informed about and has access to appropriate birth control methods to prevent unintended pregnancies.

 

Other Options:

 

  •  Option A: Blood pressure monitoring and pelvic examinations are important but may not be the primary focus at this stage.
  • Option C: Pap smears are done as per guidelines for cervical cancer screening.

 

Educational Objective: Contraceptive counseling is an important component of the post-natal visit

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition pg 697
